title: The British Tribe Next Door, another clichéd portrayal of Africa we don't need
text:
The British Tribe Next Door is problematic and reinforces dangerous stereotypes (Picture: Channel 4)

Do we really need another portrayal of an African tribe with all the clichés of naked breasts, make-up and a primal look?

The premise of Channel 4’s new show The British Tribe Next Door is to relocate Scarlett Moffatt and her family to the Namibian desert to live among the Himba tribe for one month. There the family erects their quintessentially British-style house and we follow whatever funny situations that may arise.

Straightaway we are on shaky ground.

While the show offers viewers an opportunity to look outside their own living room and national borders, it is wasting any potential it (arguably) might have to enlighten us or prompt reflection. It simplifies the Himba culture as an ‘exotic other’ next to the ‘normal’ British family – and as such reinforces dangerous, racist stereotypes.

For several years, SAIH, an organisation of students and academics in Norway the I work for, has run the Radi-Aid project, urging media and NGOs to avoid stereotypical portrayals of the global south.

Our project also promotes a more nuanced approach as an antidote to an – already simplified – image of Africa and ‘poor countries’ in Western media.

Sometimes we come across creative and informative presentations of African contexts and feel that the world is moving in the right direction. Then, suddenly, a show like The British Tribe Next Door pops up and we are reminded that we all still have a long way to go.

The star of the show is TV-celebrity Scarlett Moffatt. The show puts her and the Moffatt family at the centre, while the Himba tribe serves as the show’s ‘entertainment’ factor.

An emotional moment is presented when Scarlett Moffatt starts to cry because of a Himba woman’s first encounter with a mirror. To the woman, it looks like ‘water on the wall’ and she is fascinated by her own reflection. The British TV star finds this thought-provoking, but mainly because it reminds her of her own insecurities connected to body image.

The Himba tribe is there only so the Moffatts can tell their story, not the other way around.

A replica of Scarlett’s family home was rebuilt in Namibia (Picture: Channel 4)

One might argue that it’s good to give the British audience a peek into the world of a secluded people in Namibia. If only the show had used this opportunity to expand our world view.

But the information provided about the tribe is basic and generic. As the first segment outlines: ‘The Himba are semi-nomadic… some have moved to towns and cities, but in this village they seldom see the outside world.’ That’s about it.

Advertisement

Although it is not the entertainment industry’s responsibility to educate the public on international relations, do we really need another stereotypical and clichéd portrayal of an African tribe?

One of the wonders of the modern world is that we have so much access to information and that people all around the globe can communicate their own reality.

This is also about combating our Western legacy of being exposed to images of Africa as a continent of primitive people with a lack of agency – the capacity of someone to act of their own free will. Even in aid commercials from Africa, it is rare to see doctors and nurses from the actual countries.

We still maintain the divide between the modern white man and the savage black African, even though we know that the image is more complex.

In this sense, The British Tribe Next Door nurtures an old-fashioned view of the global south, and, quite frankly, we should be further down the road by now.
